newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - Feb 28.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - Feb 28.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Friday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
BUSINESS DAY
- The South African economy has remained surprisingly strong despite last year's interest hikes, with trade booming and economic growth respectable.

- Anglovaal minerals and mining arms Avmin is leading an international consortium that is bidding for the lion's share of assets in the privatisation of Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM), industry sources say.

- Murray & Roberts, South Africa's largest construction and engineering group, posted an 18-percent decline in attributable earnings to 145 million rand in the six months to December, knocked by increased provisions for delayed offshore projects and an 84-percent surge in interest paid.

- The Steyn report on apartheid dirty tricks by the military did not contain sufficient evidence to prosecute the head of South Africa's chemical weapons programme Wouter Basson, and this forced government to reemploy him to protect the integrity of the programme, Deputy Defence Minister Ronnie Kasrils said on Thursday.
BUSINESS REPORT

- Gold leapt more that $8 on Thursday to a high of $362.50 from $353.50 an ounce overnight before falling back in late trade to just over $360, and platinum surged on fears of a possible strike at Russia's main platinum producer, Norilsk.

- Harmony, the leading gold producer in the Randgold stable, has bought the original Saaiplaas mine in the Free State from Anglo's Freegold for 75 million rands in a further rationalisation of mineral rights ownership in the area.

- Meltz Success, which is owned by and supplies the Edgars group, on Thursday denied it had been party to any fraudulent or illegal transactions relating to imports through Namibia's Walvis Bay. It said all its imports were under legal and valid permits.
- Some of the most powerful investors in New York are itching to get a piece of the little-known Lima bond, which is sold in Zambia, a salesman at Investec said on Thursday.
SAKE BEELD
- South Africa's manufacturing business is apparently increasing its export trade and the improvement could probably have a positive influence on economic growth this year.
- Expectations that interest rates could decrease in the forseeable future took a serious knock on Thursday.
- Murray & Roberts Holdings retained its interim dividend on 14.5 cents per share, eventhough its headline earnings in the six months to end December fell by 65 percent to 18 cents per share.
THE STAR

- Schoolchildren were the victims of racial abuse and had to be escorted to their transport by teachers when residents of Malvern in eastern Johannesburg protested about the closure of a street in front of a school on Thursday. The school applied to have the road closed after two pupils were hurt while crossing the road.

- Sandton's rates payments plunged in December when residents and businesses were billed 50.1 million rands but paid only 27.4 million rands, according to figures released by the Gauteng provincial government this week.

- Gauteng education officials have decided to allow parents to scruitinise their children's matric examination scripts in a move that holds serious implications for a department still reeling from last year's examination fiasco.

- Mamelodi's "people's doctor" Fabian Ribeiro was assassinated because he gave medical treatment to "activists and terrorists", former Vlakplass commander Brigadier Jack Cronje told the Truth and Reconciliation Commission's amnesty committee in Pretoria on Thursday.
